item.title: Basic RegEx
item.description: RegEx is one of the most useful parts of Python in my opinion and as a biochemistry major, it is very handy for manipulating DNA sequences. Using reticulate to combine both R and Python, we can see that the RegEx can find instances of a sequence in a longer sequence and this can be helpful to locate the sequences digested by restiction enzymes. library(reticulate) import re string5="" re.findall(r"A[ATCG]TAAT|GC[AG][AT]TG", string5) ## ['GCGTTG', 'ATTAAT', 'GCAATG', 'ACTAAT']

item.title: Some other cool projects
item.description: One of the classes that I really enjoyed here at UT was CS324E which is Elements of Graphics and Visualization. We created a lot of cool graphics and animations projects and even made games. This first one was my final project and definitely my favorite. We made a game from start to finish to catch all of Santa’s Lost Presents! The demo video can be viewed here or below.

item.title: Just a little more about me...
item.description: Hello! I am currently a senior here at the University of Texas at Austin and plan to graduate in May 2021. I am originally from Dallas, TX and moved to Austin for school. After my years at UT, I hope to go into the medical field but for now I currently enjoy the jobs I have including teaching as a undergraduate TA and tutor and working with a doctor as a clinical assistant.

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: CHARLEEN TA (ct28558) Data Wrangling and Data Exploration Instructions A knitted R Markdown document (ideally HTML) and the raw R Markdown file (as .Rmd) should both be submitted to Canvas by 11:59pm on 10/11/2020. These two documents will be graded jointly, so they must be consistent (i.e., don’t change the R Markdown file without also updating the knitted document). The text of the document should provide a narrative structure around your code/output.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: Modeling Instructions A knitted R Markdown document (preferably HTML) and the raw R Markdown file (as .Rmd) should both be submitted to Canvas by 11:59pm on the due date. These two documents will be graded jointly, so they must be consistent (i.e., don’t change the R Markdown file without also updating the knitted document). Knit an html copy too, for later! In the .Rmd file for Project 2, you can copy the first code-chunk into your project .

item.title: Projects
item.description: Check out some of my coding projects below: Wrangling & Exploratory Data Analysis Modeling, Inference, Prediction --
